Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis is going haywire.

Dialogue.Line: What's he done?
Doctor, do something!
I'm trying to!
We're not going to make it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everyone is being thrown across the room and back as the Doctor fights the controls. Soon everything settles down.

Dialogue.Line: I have it back in control again.
Here, we're landing. Look. Coming at a fair rate.
Oh, thank the Lord for that. You know, Doctor, I'll never ask you to do that again.
Huh? Oh, no. There must have been a reason for that.
Anyway, Doctor, you've done it. It's Mars. It must be. You're landing the Tardis exactly where you said you would.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis materialises amongst magnificent desolation.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, wait a mo! This don't look like Mars to me.
How would you know? You never seen it.
No, Duchess, but I have seen pictures of the moon's surface and that's what this looks like.
That's the moon?
Doctor, is it the moon?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor nods.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, well, you weren't too far out, were you? Only about two hundred million miles.
All right, let's move on. While we can.
Now wait a minute!
What?
You don't expect to land us on the moon and let us fly off just like that, do you?
Yeah, at least let us have a look around!
That picture canna be the moon. The moon's way up in the sky.
Where do you think you're going?
You're not going to tell us there's no shore leave.
Ah, please, Doctor. The Tardis isn't out of control or anything is it?
Oh no, no, no. It was just a bumpy landing, that's all.
Yeah?
Well, if you must go ashore, only half an hour.
Right.
Super.
You can't go ashore like that! You need space suits. There's no atmosphere out there. Come on, there's some in the chest.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is still staring at the scanner.

Dialogue.Line: We'll maybe meet the old man in the moon.
You won't meet nobody mate if you don't get some gear on.
What? Oh aye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Some time later, all four of them are suited up and they leave the Tardis to look around.

Dialogue.Line: Come on now, let's go over here.
Hey, look at this.
It's deserted.
I don't think I like it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Polly sees a pulsating light.

Dialogue.Line: Look, over there.
I'll don't see anything.
What did you see?
Some sort of great glow in the sky.
It's probably your eyes getting used to the lunar light, hey, Doctor?
Possibly.
What do we need these great clogs for?
Try a little jump.
All right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Polly takes a small jump and rises about ten feet, falling slowly and rolling gently as she lands. Ben and Jamie copy her and collide.

Dialogue.Line: Careful! One tear in that space suit and you'll suffocate.
You never told me you'd taken ballet lessons, Ben.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Polly takes a big jump to a the crater rim.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, it's easy.
Look out, here I come.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie jumps too far and goes over the rim and out of sight.

Dialogue.Line: Where's he gone?
Over there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: From the rim of the crater they look down on a large domed building.

Dialogue.Line: What on Earth? Look!
Blimey! What is it?
Doctor, what is it?
I don't know.
Hey, I can see Jamie. There he is.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is lying unconscious by the dome.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, there's somebody coming out.
Come on, let's go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two spacesuited figures come out of the dome's airlock and take Jamie inside. The Doctor, Ben and Polly hurry to the dome and Ben knocks on the airlock. Then it slides open. After a brief pause, they all go in.

The moonbase is a weather control centre. A small team of scientists govern weather patterns on Earth using a powerful device called the Gravitron. A map of the Earth dominates one wall, and the Gravitron probe is in a transparent dome on one side of the room with it's power controls in an insulated room. Each person wears a numbered uniform, and the gravitron technicians wear protective headgear. They are monitoring a Pacific hurricane or typhoon when one of the workers collapses. An alarm sounds.

Dialogue.Line: (2nd in command, French) What on Earth is it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Played by Andre Maranne, possibly the only genuine French actor the BBC knew.
A web of black lines covers the stricken man's face.

Dialogue.Line: (base commander) I don't know. Get him along to the Medical unit.
But Doctor Evans has gone down with it as well.
Yes, I know that but the relief Doctor from Earth should be here on the next shuttle rocket.
Yes, yes, of course. Bob, give me a hand, will you?
Yes, right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benoit and Bob carry the man out.

Dialogue.Line: And Jules, you take over. Come on, it won't bite you. There must be some source to this infection. Look, we'd better get the lads in here and tell them what's happening. Get them on the blower, would you, Nils?
(the number 3, Danish) Okay, Hobby. (into intercom) Nils speaking. We, er, we've got a bit of a flap on up here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hobson is distracted by the arrival of the Doctor, Polly and Ben next door.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Hobson wants a word with you all in weather control room. Quick as you can.
Hello. Where did you lot spring from? Don't tell me the shuttle rocket's arrived already?
No, it hasn't.
There was another one with them, sir. Bob's taken him along to the Medical unit. He's all right. He's just knocked himself out or something.
Oh no, if we haven't got enough troubles already. Have they been through the sterile room?
Yes, Hobby.
We don't want to cause you any trouble. Just let us collect our young friend and we'll be off.
Hey, not so fast.
Please, let me go and see Jamie.
I will take you there, mademoiselle, if you come with me.
All right, young lady. You can carry on.
This way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Polly and Benoit leave.

Dialogue.Line: But I'd just like to have a word with you two. You could do with a extra bacteria check by the look of it.
Bacteria check?
That's what I said.
Well, thanks.
I'll have you know our Tardis is as sterile as
Tardis?
Our space craft.
They're all here, sir. Any time you're ready.
Right. Well, we'll learn about your spacecraft a little later. Meanwhile, you'd better come along with me, meet my team and listen to what I have to say.
Thank you very much.
Well, you know what this place is?
Well, it looks like some sort of weather control centre? Ah, yes. And that's the thing with which you control the weather. That's the culprit, then.
Ay?
That's what gave us such a bumpy landing. Some sort of gravity device?
Some sort of gravity device. You are from Earth, aren't you?
Yes.
Well, where've you been for the past 20 years. Every school kid knows about the Gravitron in there.
Ah, yes. It must be about the year 2050, Ben.
We've got a proper Rip Van Winkle here. It's 2070, in case you'd like to know.
There you are. I was only twenty years out.
Well, before we all forget what century we're in, I'd better tell you why I've called you here.
Won't you introduce us first? I am a Doctor.
A Doctor? You're arrived just in time. We need your help.
Ah. Do you?
I'll see you in a moment. Now, this virus
Well, I may be able to help you if you'll introduce us.

Right, Doctor. You'd better meet them all. We're all scientists here, you see. No room for idle hands, I see to that. Roger Benoit, beside you there, is my assistant. He takes over as Chief Scientist if anything happens to me. He's a physicist like me and Joe Benson there. Nils, our mad Dane, is an astronomer and mathematician as is Charlie here. Ralph, Jules and Franz are geologists. When they're not acting as cooks, looks-outs, general and, you know, handymen.
And this is where you control the Earth's weather? I see.
The gravitron there controls the tides, the tides controls the weather. And from this console here we plot it all on that map. Simple, eh?
Oh, yeah, very simple. Wish we'd had all this back in 1966.
Was it a bad year then?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An alarm sounds.

Dialogue.Line: What's that? What's happened?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man has collapsed inside the gravitron chamber.

Dialogue.Line: It's Jim. Quick, Franz, take over here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Franz puts on a helmet and goes into the chamber. Ralph and John carry Jim to the medical unit.

Dialogue.Line: Indicator Five over the Pacific is starting to move.
What does that mean?
Some form of change in the weather.
We're soon hear from Earth what it means.
Here it comes!
International Space Control Headquarters Earth calling Weather Control Moon. Come in please.
Moonport standing by.
Earth calling Weather Control Moon. Come in please.
Moonport standing by.
Hobson here.
What's happening up there? The hurricane you were guiding is now 45 degrees off course. It's threatening Hawaii.
One of my men was taken ill. We're operational again now.
The controller would like to know the cause of the illness.
Yes, so would we. We've now got three men down with this mystery virus in the past few hours, including the doctor.
One moment please. Stand by for further instructions.
Just hang on another couple of minutes, lads. We'd better hear what the great Mister Rinberg has to say.
Hobby?
Yes.
There it is again. I'll play it back to you.
Yes, so would we. We've now got three men down with this mystery virus in the past few hours, including the Doctor.
One moment please. Stand by for further instructions.
Hear the big noise ratio on that re-run? We're being monitored again.
Monitored?
Someone, not too far away from the base, is listening to every word we say.
Moonbase, Moonbase. Come in, Moonbase.
Still standing by.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An alien spacecraft is concealed a short way from the dome, monitoring the conversation.

Dialogue.Line: Well?
Your instructions are to send blood samples back to Earth for investigation.
Well, when can we do that? The next shuttle rocket's not for another month.
Then they must be put on that rocket. In the meantime the Moonbase is to be put in quarantine.
Quarantine? What if these men aren't fit enough to get back to work. I shall need replacements.
If you radio information about this virus, we'll do our best to identify it and suggest treatment.
I demand to speak to Rinberg.
The controller is busy. I'm sorry. Over and out.
That whole conversion was monitored by someone or something.
Oh, never mind about that now. That Rinberg fellow just won't talk to you. How can we trace down this mystery illness with the doctor himself down with it.
We'd better get out of these things and see how Jamie is. Perhaps I could be of help in the sick bay now.
Anything you can do. Bob!
Yes, Mister Hobson?
Show him to the Medical unit, will you?
Yes, of course, sir. Will you come this way, please.
Yes. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bob, Ben and the Doctor leave.

Dialogue.Line: Well, you all heard the position. We don't know what this infection is or how it got into the base, but I want you all to take extra precautions while this emergency is on. We may be short-handed for quite a while.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Polly is attaching a medical monitor to Jamie's chest.

Dialogue.Line: Is this how it goes, Doctor?
Yes, that's right. Then this unit automatically controls the pulse, the temperature and the breathing.
A sort of electronic doctor.
Yes. Almost got striped trousers.
And it even gives him medicines too?
Yes, it will do very nearly everything.
It can't be nice to him. Oh dear. How do you think he is, Doctor?
Oh, he's not too bad. He's a bit concussed and feverish, but he'll be all right with rest.
The Piper. The McCrimmon Piper. Don't let him get me!
Piper?
Some legend of his clan. As far as I can make out, this piper appears to a McCrimmon just before he dies.
Has this phantom piper appeared to Jamie yet?
You don't believe it, do you?
No, but he does. It's important to him.
He keeps asking us to keep the piper away from him.
Good. Well, we'll see whether we can do just that.
Well, carry on, nurse.
Well, at least I tried to help. With a ward full of sick men and no doctor, somebody's got to do something.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A patient is groaning.

Dialogue.Line: I wonder who this is?
Don't get too near, Polly. Have a look on his chart.
Yes, that's a good idea.
It's Doctor Evans.
Oh, yes. The station doctor. He was the first one to get it.
He looks one of the worst.
There's something about this epidemic that I don't quite understand. It's not like a real disease at all. It's almost as if
Not real? What more do you want?
I don't know. But there are certain signs and symptoms which don't add up. Ben, I want you to go along to the control room and keep an eye on things.
Well, how?
I don't know. Give a hand, do anything, but keep your eyes and ears open.
Right.
There's something very wrong here. Very wrong indeed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The base is on it's night cycle. Benoit returns from a break.

Dialogue.Line: Still up, Hobby? Why not take a rest. Go and get some sleep.

How can I rest with that thing up the spout. You know the score as well as I do. Five units off centre we lift half London into space. Five more and the Atlantic water level goes up three feet. Rinberg just doesn't understand the pressure we're under. Hey, you! What do you thinking you're doing skulking there?
Well, I was just wondering if I can help, sir.
Help? How could you help?
We could do with an extra pair of hands. He can help me.
Well, keep him away from me, that's all. All right, I'll go and lie down. Call me if anything happens.
Yes, of course.
Oh, by the way. There were two more of those momentary drops in air pressure while I was on. I've put them in the log.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hobson leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Well, there are some coffee cups to clear away if you wish to be helpful. And er, oh er, Ralph, that is, no. 14, needs a hand down in the food store. Can you find your way there?
Yeah, I'll find it.
Good boy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ralph is loading a trolley with supplies from the shelves and ticking them off a list. He picks up a sack of sugar and the contents spill onto the floor through a hole in the bottom. He throws it into the waste disposal.

Dialogue.Line: (american) Anyone would think we've got rats up here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A tin falls.

Dialogue.Line: Who's that? Who is it?
It's only me, mate.
Oh, for heaven's sake. Don't go sneaking around like that.
Blimey, you lot aren't half edgy.
You will be too, mate, if you've been up here long enough. Say, are you responsible for the broken bags here.
Come off it. I've only just arrived, haven't I?
Okay. See and you can find that light. Round the back there, most likely.
Okay.
Let's see. We still need some more milk and sugar.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As Ralph searches the shelves a huge figure looms out of the darkness. There's an electric shock sound. Ralph's body is dragged away before Ben returns.

Dialogue.Line: Number 14? Ralph? Where are you? Scarpered. Funny bloke.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Polly is dozing.

Dialogue.Line: What's that?
Shh. It's all right, Polly, it's only me. We don't want to wake everybody up, do we? You look as though you could do with some sleep yourself.
I'm all right. What have you got there?
Oh, I've been doing a little investigation.
A piece of silver paper. What is it?
I don't know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The lights dim.

Dialogue.Line: What's happened?
Oh, it's nothing. It probably just a changeover in the time cycle.
What do you mean?
Oh well, you see, it's rather interesting really. You see, on the moon they have a fortnight of days and a fortnight of nights.
Well?
Well, it's obvious, isn't it? They have to make their own day and night artificially up here, or it would upset their whole biological time clock.
Their what?
They won't know whether they were coming or going. Get it?
Yes.
Clever girl. QED. That's why it's dark up here.
Oh, I see what you mean. Yes, of course. How stupid of me.
Of course along at the control centre it's probably broad daylight. Polly, you wouldn't be making fun of me, would you?
No.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man screams.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor Evans!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Evans is sweating heavily, and delirious.

Dialogue.Line: The hand. No, don't touch me. No. The silver hand. (scream)
Doctor, is he?
Yes, I'm afraid he is.
What are we going to do?
What did he mean by the silver hand? I'd better report this to Mister Hobson.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben is reporting Ralph's disappearance.

Dialogue.Line: Can't find him? Ralph?
Well, I was helping him load some stores and he just disappeared.
What, in this place? Well, there are only nineteen of us.
Have you tried his quarters?
Yeah.
Why didn't you report this to me?
Well, I'm just telling you now, aren't I?
Now what is the matter?
I'm very sorry. It's Doctor Evans.
Well?
I'm afraid he's dead.
Dead? No.
This must be reported at once.
Yes, yes. No! No, we haven't got enough data yet. You know what they're like down there. I'll come to the sick bay with you. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie suddenly sits up and stares at the tall silver figure in front of him. It has a blank metal face with round eye holes and a slit for the mouth. Tubes come from where its ears should be and connect at a round device on the top of it's head. We seen something like this before, but Jamie hasn't.

Dialogue.Line: No! No, I'll not go with you. Do you hear me, piper? No, leave me. Leave me, I'll not go with you, do you hear me? Leave me. No, I'll not go with you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Cyberman goes round the other beds.

Dialogue.Line: I'll fight you every inch of the way. I'll not go with ya. No. No.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Cyberman takes the blanket off another patient and carries off the struggling man.

Dialogue.Line: Leave me, piper. No, leave me, I'll not go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Polly returns with the water for Jamie. She screams. Hobson, the Doctor, Ben and two other men run in.

Dialogue.Line: Polly! Polly, what's happened?
Oh, Doctor! Doctor, it was horrible. A great creature like a, like a Cyberman.
It's all right. Don't be frightened. Whatever it was, it's all gone now.
Yes, but Doctor, the Cyberman was carrying one of the patients out!
Cyberman?
Cyberman? What are you talking about?
I'm sure it was. I'm sure it was!
Are you sure?
I'll not go with you!
All right, mate. You're safe now. Take it easy.
Yes it did, I promise you.

She's right. There's another one gone. Sam, Jules, you've got to find these men. They can't just disappear in a place this size. Search every square inch, don't come back until you've found them. Now move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sam and Jules leave.

Dialogue.Line: Now, supposing you tell me your story. What did you see?

Well, I went out to get Jamie some water and when I came back I saw this giant man or creature or something just going out of the door carrying one of the patients like a doll. I think it was a Cyberman.
Forget the Cyberman part. Then what?
Well, then nothing. The door shut and then you came in.
What do you know about all this?
Nothing. Absolutely nothing.
We'll see about that in a minute. This thing you saw, what was it like?
It was enormous and silver, and it had holes in it's head for eyes, like a robot!
A robot?
But the Cybermen were all killed when Mondas blew up, weren't they?
Stop this Cyberman nonsense. There were Cybermen, every child knows that, but they were all destroyed ages ago.
So we all thought.

That's enough. Now let's have a little calm thinking. For the past two weeks a completely unknown disease has appeared in the base. People drop in their tracks, they develop this black pattern on their skin. Then some of the patients disappear, right? Well, they can't leave the base without wearing space suits, and there are no space suits missing, so where are they?
I must say it does sound a little odd.
More than a little. Well I do know one thing. A new disease starts, people disappear and then you turn up.
And you think we did it.
Oh, come off it, we haven't done a thing.
That's as maybe. I don't know who you are, what you are or where you come from. But you can get off the moon now.
Yeah, well that suits me fine. The sooner the better.
No, Ben. We can't go yet.
Well, why not? They don't want us here.
Because there is something evil here and we must stay.
Evil? Don't be daft.

Evil is what I meant. There are some corners of the universe which have bred the most terrible things. Things which act against everything that we believe in. They must be fought. This disease, for instance. It isn't really a disease at all, but I can help you with it. You'll see. I'll find the cause for you.
Will you, indeed?
Yes, certainly. I just need to examine a few things, that's all. It should be simple.
Well, I'm not sure. I'll tell you what I'll do. I'll give you just one Earth day cycle to find the cause.
Earth what?
Twenty four hours.
But that's no time at all.
It's all the time you're going to get. Then you get off the moon, complete with this bloke here.
But you can't move him. He's very ill.
We accept. Now tell me, you have pathological equipment here, yes?
Yes, Evans was working on an extensive research project. It's all in here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go to an area marked off by a ring of workbenches and shelves.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, I'll have a look in here.
It's quite a small unit. We're not equipped to deal with a full scale epidemic, you understand. Do you think you can manage?
Yes, I think I can.
Right. Well, I'll leave you to it. But don't forget, twenty four hours.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hobson leaves. The Doctor takes a tray of items over to a patient.

Dialogue.Line: What are you going to do, Doctor?
We're going to start with this one.
Listen, are you really a medical doctor?
Yes, I think I was once, Polly. I think I took a degree once in Glasgow. 1888 I think. Lister. Hold that for me, will you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor swabs a black-lined hand, and the arm convulses.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right. He's quite unconscious.
Well look, what can we do to help?
I shall need to examine everything. Clothes, boots, food, towels, soap, everything. Will you get them for me, please?
Have you any idea what it might be?
No. Not an idea. But we'll find it out.
I don't understand it. I'm sure there's a lack of co-ordination somewhere.
Yes, but where?
On the indicators, look. It should be steady as a rock.
The fault must be in the gravitron.
Nils, here.
Yes Hobby?
I'm going to run a test. Move the probe and we'll see if the indicators move the right distance on the map. Okay?
Right.
Benoit, keep an eye on the probe itself, will you?
Okay. All yours, Bob.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benoit walks over to watch the gravitron probe.

Dialogue.Line: Deflect probe five degrees, now. Way off. Five degrees should put them over Iceland. Move the probe back again.
Right.
The probe seems to deflect all right.
The fault must be here. This could be a major disaster if we can't stabilise the Earth's field.
If we lose that hurricane, Mister Hobson, all hell will break loose on the Earth. I've a wife and family.
Yeah, you're not the only one. Roger, check the potentiometers.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benoit puts on a helmet and enters the control area.

Dialogue.Line: Nils, check the gravitation units. Shake it up. We haven't got much time.
Field stabilising at 48, Mister Hobson.
Prepare to move probe. Check co-ordinates. We've got to hold that hurricane in the Pacific. Stand by. Now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benoit returns.

Dialogue.Line: Twenty degree tilt complete.
The field's not correcting. We'll have to increase the reactor power.
You can't do that. The torus will burn out.
It's all we can do.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The communication centre comes into life.

Dialogue.Line: International Space Control. R/T: Earth calling.
Earth calling Moon Weather Control. Stand by. Stand by for the controller. R/T: This is Moonbase. Come in please.
We wish to speak to Mister Hobson.
Hobson speaking.
Stand by for the Controller.
Right. He's actually going to speak to us this time.
Controller Rinberg speaking. Is that you, Hobson?
Yes, Rinberg.
The directional fields are showing a progressive error. Reports have come in of wide-spread pressure fluctuations in Atlantic zone 6. You must get the gravitron back into balance.
We're trying to compensate by re-aligning the probe. We have an error in the servos.
Well, there's no sign of any improvement here. We've just had a report from Miami, Florida. Thirty minutes ago they were enjoying clear skies and a heat wave. Now Hurricane Lucy is right overhead.
There is only one thing to do.
What's that?
Shut it down.
What, switch the gravitron off?!
Yes, it's the only chance.
We can't do that, man. The collapse of the gravity would devastate half the globe. There'd be storms, whirlwinds, hurricanes.

I overheard your conversation. It's quite out of the question. You're not to shut down the gravitron under any circumstances, and that's an order. I think perhaps you don't appreciate how serious the situation already is.
I bet he gets a knighthood.

We spent years in a general assembly negotiating methods of agreement between farmers and landowners and so on. Now the weather's out of control they're after our blood, and I must say I can't blame them. You've got to get that thing under control, quickly. Now please get on with it.
Earth control, over and out.

Well, you're all in the picture. We've got trouble, bad trouble, we haven't got much time. We're going to run through every circuit, every field pattern, every damn nut and bolt on Charlie boy in there until he's running sweet and smooth. A full class A test, in fact. Now you all know what to do so let's get on with it.
Okay, Chief.
Right, we'll start on the main tape programme.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A proper computer bank, with turning magnetic tapes and stuff.

Dialogue.Line: It's running now.
Right, give me the analogue value on module 6, will you?
Will do. They look all right. A at 10 millivolts. B at 15 millivolts, C at 26. That fits, doesn't it?
Yes, they're at normal levels. Roger, finish checking here, will you? The answer may be in the control panel.
Okay. I'll sing out the binary conversion values, you check them on read out, okay?
Right.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has stuck in and is taking samples of fibres from Benoit's shirt.

Dialogue.Line: Channel one.
Jah.
Eight.
Right.
One.
Mm-hm.
Three.
Jah.
Four.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor starts plucking at Benoit's trouser leg.

Dialogue.Line: Jah.
Six.
Right.
Eight.
Right.
Twelve.
Jah.
Right?
Right. All spot on.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benoit notices the Doctor and turns on him.

Dialogue.Line: Eh là, qu'est-ce que vous fabriquez ici, imbécile d'idiot ! Vous n'avez rien d'autre à faire ? Vous croyez que nous sommes en train de nous amuser ? Oh, come on. Get out of the way.
Enchanté, Monsieur.
Now, where were we? Ah, yes, the fluid servo pressures. I reckon this is probably where the fault is.
Er, do you want them all or just the main tank readings?
The main will do.
Right. Header one, 45 pounds.
Yes.
Header two, 47
Yes.
Three, 42.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor starts unfastening Nils' bootlaces.

Dialogue.Line: Yes.
Sine values equivalent.
They all fit. Nothing there.
It must be the potentiometer net, then.
Looks like it. Take us some time to do that. We'll need the digital voltmeter.
Right, I'll get it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nils steps out of his boot.

Dialogue.Line: What the blazes are you doing?
I'm just collecting specimens.
Specimens? Oh, yes. Well, get on with it.
We're nearly out of this interferon stuff.
Oh. Well you'd better go and ask Mister Hobson where the rest is.
Yeah, right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben leaves. Jamie groans.

Dialogue.Line: Shh. It's all right, Jamie, it's all right. You're going to get better but you must lie still.
Oh, what is this place? Is it the home of the piper?
No, we're on the moon. You know, the moon, up in the sky.

I can't hold it. It's accelerating too fast.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The screen goes white.

Dialogue.Line: Look out, man. You're on the sun.
But that's where it's heading.
The acceleration, it's gigantic!
Get R/T contact with the ship.
No good, sir. The Doppler effect. It's going too fast.
They've had it, I'm afraid.
The sun.
Yes.
Will somebody please tell us what it all means?
The rocket has been deflected towards the sun. Nothing can save them now.
Save them? What are you talking about?
From plunging into the sun.
But the sun's millions of miles away.
Once they get into the sun's gravity belt they can't change course. It may take a week but they'll end up there just the same.
What on earth could have caused it?
The rocket was deflected off course, but why and how?
Deflected? Yes, of course. The gravitron.
Have the Cybermen got a gravity weapon, do you think?
No, they haven't but we have.
You're not suggesting that
There's only one way that rocket could have been deflected into the sun. From this very room!
I see what you mean.
Of course, the gravitron. Benson, he must
I told you he'd been on duty too long.
If it is Benson.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They look through the gravitron control room. Evans turns around.

Dialogue.Line: It's Evans!
But he was in the medical room!
They must have got control of them again.
And the other men in there?
They may not be affected yet. Get along to the medical room. Barricade the door with everything you can find. Keep them in there at all costs!
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The other men are being activated. Number 10 and two others get up.

Dialogue.Line: Well, that's all right. We haven't passed any of them.
Well, maybe it was only Evans who's been reactivated.
Aye. We'd better keep watch just here.
We could stick that thing against the door
It wouldn't hold them for long, I'm thinking.
They're not Cybermen, mate. They're just flesh and blood like us. Come on, get hold of the other end.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They start to carry the metal table when Jamie drops his end.

Dialogue.Line: Hey!
Behind you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man starts to walk through the door.

Dialogue.Line: Quick! Ram him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Number ten get the thin metal rammed into his stomach. He falls back.

Dialogue.Line: Press the locking button.
It won't hold for long, will it.
No. Look, get those chairs and we'll block 'em in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The controlled men use a strip of metal to prise the doors apart.

Dialogue.Line: Evans, can you hear me? Listen, Evans, this is Hobson talking. Evans, you've got to concentrate. Your brain has been altered by the Cybermen. You're being controlled by them, anyhow. We've got one or two of those things as well, you know. You can't shoot all of us so why not be a good fellow and come out of there.
What's he doing in there? Look at the field reactors.
Huh?
We must get back control soon. He could flood half of Europe if he keeps the gravitron aligned with spring tides.
That settles it, we'll have to rush him. Get those weapons out.
Resistance is useless. All further ships from Earth will be deflected. Open the airlock to us. If you do not we shall destroy the base and you will be eliminated.
Can you hear me?
Everything you have said in the past half hour has been overheard.
Well you can hear this too, then. We're not done yet and we'll fight you to the last man. You'll never get inside this base.
We are in it already.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a bang and everyone clutches their throats and hangs on as the air rushes out.

Dialogue.Line: They've punctured the dome!
The oxygen masks! Quick everyone, take a mask. Over there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nils, Ben and Jamie get to a set of three masks in the ceiling. The Doctor has got one at the console Polly is hanging on to.
The dome is cracking.

Dialogue.Line: I do hope we don't lose too much oxygen.
Can we patch it, do you think?
We can try.
Give me a hand off, will you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benoit helps Hobson take off his lab coat.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, I can't breathe!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor tries to pass her a mask.

Dialogue.Line: Put this on your face.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hobson and Benoit plug the crack with the coat.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, thank heavens. I can breath again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The coat starts to get sucked through the hole.

Dialogue.Line: Oh no!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The coat is sucked through the hole and flies across the moon.

Dialogue.Line: Is there anything else we can patch it with?
No, nothing. Wait. Over there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It's the coffee tray.

Dialogue.Line: Slide it to me but don't let go of it. We have to do it in one action. No second chance. Okay, ready?
Oui.
Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: This firmly blocks the hole and the pressure gauges rise again.

Dialogue.Line: Stopped them for the moment.
I wonder for how long.
Well, let's have a look.
Polly! Are you all right?
Oh yes. Oh. Oh, where's that air coming from?
Reserve tanks of oxygen.
Oh. Well why couldn't we have had those before?
And lose all our oxygen?
Oh, I see. It's so quiet.
Yes, it is, isn't it. The gravitron's stopped!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Evans is slumped over the console.

Dialogue.Line: Quick, before he comes to! Ben, Jamie!
Joe!
We've barricaded the sick bay with half the tables and chairs in the base but it won't hold forever, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes the helmet and control piece off Evans.

Dialogue.Line: Well done, Ben. Here's another one for you. **[Control room]**
What do we do with him, Doctor?
That's your problem. Just make sure he doesn't come back here for a while.
Blimey, I'll be after a job as a copper when I get back to 1966.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben and Jamie leave with Evans. The Doctor puts the control device inside his coat.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Hobson, I've got an idea.
Doctor, what do you make of this?
Made by a laser beam, I would think.
Is there anything known to science the Cybermen haven't got?
Well they haven't got a gravitron or they wouldn't be after yours.
We'll just have to stand guard in here with their cyberguns.
Not much use, I'm afraid. They are getting reinforcements.
What?
Looks like another of their spaceships.
Oh yes, there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A classic flying saucer lands.

Dialogue.Line: Another one!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And a second.

Dialogue.Line: We have brought up reinforcements with other weapons. You have one chance. You must open the entry port. You cannot stop us now. You will all be completely destroyed.
What does he mean, other weapons?
We'll soon find out. You stay here. I must report this to Mister Hobson.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nils leaves Polly in charge of the R/T.
Cybermen are unpacking crates.

Dialogue.Line: I shall count to ten. If you still stupidly remain silent. we shall fire. One
Hobby! They've got another weapon. They're going to
Yes, I know. There it is. Everybody take cover. Get down, all of you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor stays standing.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
Is the gravitron still switched on?
Yes.
Then I shall certainly stay here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A group of Cybermen aim a weapon at the base.

Dialogue.Line: Nine, ten. Fire.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A beam goes towards the base then 'bounces' off it. For some reason, this cyberweapon has recoil.

Dialogue.Line: Again. Fire.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Once again the beam bounces off the base.

Dialogue.Line: What happened?
It just deflected over the dome.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sways.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, are you all right?
Yes, of course.
The gravitron deflected it. The force field.
Yes, and that gives me an idea. What are they doing now? They're packing it away.
What'll they cook up next, I wonder?
How far down can this be aimed?
Down?
Can it be brought to bear on the surface of the moon?
I see!
Ah, well, I don't
Has it ever been tried?
No, but we should try!
With Evans gone, the gravitron is all yours.
Splendid! Je m'en occupe!
It can only go to here. Any further down and the field may affect the base.
What does that matter now?
Well, I suppose you're right.
Get someone to stand by that window and relay instructions direct to Benoit.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benoit puts on a helmet and goes into gravitron control. Polly is by the window to relay instructions. Thumbs up are sent.

Dialogue.Line: He's ready.
Start moving the probe down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The message is relayed. The approaching Cybermen stop advancing and spread out. They draw their weapons. Benoit signals that the gravitron won't go any lower.

Dialogue.Line: That's as far as it'll go.
What? But it's way over their heads. There's one chance. We'll try bringing it down by hand.
Right.
Is this still switched off?
Yes, it's off.
Round the back.
It won't go.
All your weight, once more. No, it's no use, it won't shift.
Ah, stupid of me. Of course it won't.
Why?

Well, the angular cut out. It's obvious, isn't it. You see, there's got to be a safety cut out on the angle of the probe otherwise it might affect the whole base. There, that's done it. No, no, no, stand back. Benoit can do it now.
Polly!
Switch on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the gravitron comes down to level with the moon's surface, the Cybermen start to float up and away, followed by their saucers. Big cheers from the assembled team.

Dialogue.Line: We did it!
Well, that's taken care of the Cybermen. Now then, everybody, we've got to get this gravitron in operation again as fast as we can.
I'm so sorry we damaged it.
What? Oh, yes.
Nils, rig up a temporary aerial. Call up Space Control. Tell Rinberg we will be operational in er, oh about two hours. He won't like it but it's the best we can do.
Right.
Two hours, that's all we've got to get the world's weather back under control again. Benoit, take charge of your side.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meanwhile, the Doctor, Ben, Polly and Jamie quietly leave.

Dialogue.Line: Right.
And Doctor, what the? Oh well, perhaps it's just as well. We've got enough madmen here already. Now come on, I want to see your first weather plot in two minutes.
Right, come on boys.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Safely suited up, the travellers take a last at the Moonbase before approaching the Tardis doors.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A comet-like object is streaking through space.

Dialogue.Line: Could that be them?
Possibly. And I hope it's the last we see of them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They all enter the Tardis and it dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: There we are. In perfect flight.
Yes, and look what happened last time.
Oh, that. What a lot of fuss. Just a bumpy landing, that's all. It won't happen again. I know.
What are you up to now?
Let's have a look at the time scanner.
The what?
The time scanner. Instead of the normal picture showing where we are, it gives you a glimpse of the future.
The second sight? Very dangerous.
Oh nonsense. I haven't used it very much. It's (cough) not very reliable, as you can see.
Doctor.
Hmm?
Look!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scanner shows an image of a giant claw.
